title: 113_hr84
content: The Act may be cited as the "Transportation Security Administration Ombudsman Act of 2013". It establishes the Transportation Security Administration Ombudsman Office. The Transportation Security Administration Ombudsman Act of 2013 establishes the Office of the Ombudsman within the Transportation Security Administration. The Ombudsman must have expertise in labor and employment relations with Federal agencies. The Chief Human Capital Officer of the Department of Homeland Security must notify congressional committees within 30 days of appointing, reappointing, or removing an Ombudsman. The Ombudsman must report to the Administrator of the agency to ensure independence. The Ombudsman reports to the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration and the Chief Human Capital Officer of the Department of Homeland Security in case of disputes. The Inspector General retains the authority to conduct investigations. The Ombudsman's duties include ensuring independence in executing responsibilities. The Ombudsman for Transportation Security Administration employees conducts outreach, evaluates complaints objectively, provides assistance, and informs complainants of investigation status and recommendations. The Ombudsman for Transportation Security Administration employees conducts outreach, evaluates complaints objectively, provides assistance, and informs complainants of investigation status and recommendations. The Ombudsman's responsibilities include working with the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration to address issues, maintaining confidentiality of complaints and inquiries, and submitting an annual report to congressional committees on actions taken and objectives. The Ombudsman for Transportation Security Administration employees submits an annual report to congressional committees on actions taken and objectives. The report includes statistical information on complaints, problems encountered by complainants, policy recommendations made to the Administrator, and an inventory of items described. The Ombudsman submits an annual report to congressional committees on actions taken and objectives, including an inventory of items for which action has been taken or remains to be completed, along with other relevant information. The report is submitted directly to the committees without prior comment or amendment by the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration. The Ombudsman can issue additional reports on the Office's activities. The Administrator must provide contact information for the Office on the TSA website. The term 'appropriate congressional committee' is defined in the section. A clerical amendment is made to the chapter's analysis. The chapter is amended by adding new items related to subchapter II. Authorization of Appropriations for implementing section 44946 of title 49, United States Code, as amended by this section, is set at $575,000 for each of fiscal years 2014, 2015, and 2016.
